meanings.definition: To introduce a serum, vaccine, or antigenic substance into (the body of a person or animal), especially to produce or boost immunity to a specific disease.
meanings.sent1: The doctor will inoculate the child with a flu shot to keep them healthy.
meanings.sent2: It is important to inoculate your pets against rabies to protect them.
meanings.sent3: The superhero decided to inoculate the city against the evil virus with his special powers.
meanings.sent4: Her positive attitude acted as a shield, inoculating her from negativity.
meanings.sent5: The magical potion was said to inoculate anyone who drank it from all illnesses.

meanings.definition: To protect against disease, error, or harm.
meanings.sent1: Washing your hands frequently can help inoculate you from catching a cold.
meanings.sent2: Regular exercise can inoculate your body against various health issues.
meanings.sent3: The umbrella acted as a shield, inoculating him from the unexpected rain.
meanings.sent4: Her knowledge of self-defense techniques inoculated her from potential attackers.
meanings.sent5: The antivirus software works to inoculate your computer from harmful viruses.

meanings.definition: To implant microorganisms or infectious material into (a culture medium).
meanings.sent1: The scientist will inoculate the agar plate with bacteria for the experiment.
meanings.sent2: It is crucial to inoculate the culture medium carefully to avoid contamination.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous student tried to inoculate the petri dish with glitter for fun.
meanings.sent4: The artist's creativity seemed to inoculate the canvas with vibrant energy.
meanings.sent5: The music seemed to inoculate the room with a sense of calm and relaxation.
